newsitem.title: SYRIA: Syria exports cereals worth $140 million in 1996.
newsitem.headline: Syria exports cereals worth $140 million in 1996.

text.p: Syria has exported 850,000 tonnes of cereals worth $140 million since the beginning of 1996, official sources said on Saturday.
They said Syria has exported 300,000 tonnes of wheat at around $160 to $270 per tonne, mainly to Tunisia, Turkey, Italy and North Korea.

The official newspaper Tishreen said Syria has exported 500,000 tonnes of barley, mainly to Jordan and smaller amounts to Lebanon, Cyprus, Morocco, Tunisia and Saudi Arabia at around $140 to $150 per tonne.
Syria also exported 50,000 tonnes of lentils to Egypt, India and Sri Lanka at around $400 per tonne.
Syria, which in 1996 produced over 4.2 million tonnes of wheat, achieved self-sufficiency in 1992 when it harvested around three million tonnes. It entered the cereals market in 1994.
Annual Syrian wheat consumption is around two million tonnes. Syria also stores huge amounts of wheat as a strategic reserve.
The trade in wheat and barley, grown by the private sector, is limited to the government General Establishment for Cereals Processing and Trade (GECPT) which buys the harvest from farmers.
Private producers of lentils are allowed to sell or export their crops.
Syria in 1995 produced around 1.6 million tonnes of barley, and official sources said there were plans to export over 750,000 tonnes in 1996. Syria consumes around 300,000 tonnes of barley per year.
In 1996 Syria produced 125,000 tonnes of lentils. The government bought around 65,000 tonnes. Total stored amounts in 1996 were 145,000 tonnes.
Official sources said Syria will aim to export the 1994-1995 lentils storage of around 80,000 tonnes before next year's harvest.
Recent irrigation plans helped Syria boost cereals production. High international prices and local storage problems made Syria look to exporting some of its grain output, the sources said.
